Homage to such bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas in the worlds of the ten directions, immeasurable and boundless.
I respectfully bow to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all sages.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
Now, repenting of all karmas in general, I will now in order repent of each and every specific karma.
Whether in general or specific, coarse or fine, light or heavy, whether spoken or not, may all be eliminated according to their categories.
As for specific repentance, first repent the three karmas of the body, then the four karmas of the mouth, and then the other hindrances, bowing in sequence.

As for the three karmas of the body, the first is killing, as explained in the sutras. Considerate of oneself, one can take it as a standard. Do not kill, do not use a stick. Although birds and beasts are different, they all cherish life and fear death. This matter is the same.

If one investigates these sentient beings, from beginningless time, they may have been one's parents, siblings, or relatives of the six relations. Due to karmic causes and conditions, they transmigrate through the six realms, coming to life and dying, changing forms and transforming their lot, no longer recognizing each other. Yet now one harms them and eats their flesh, cutting off the seeds of great kindness.
Therefore the Buddha said:
Even if one obtains leftover food, one should think of it as the flesh of one's starving child.
How much more so for eating fish and meat?
He also said:ğŸ”½If one eats the flesh of sentient beings, it is the same as eating one's own flesh.
'For the sake of profit, killing sentient beings, using money to buy the flesh of sentient beings, both are evil karma, and after death one falls into the wailing hell.'
Therefore, know that killing and eating have sins as deep as the ocean and as heavy as mountains.
However, disciples, from beginningless time until now, not encountering good friends, have all engaged in this karma.
Therefore, the sutra says:
'The sin of killing can cause sentient beings to fall into the hells and hungry ghosts to suffer.

If in the animal realm, one receives the body of tigers, leopards, jackals, wolves, hawks, and falcons, or the body of poisonous snakes, vipers, and scorpions, always harboring evil thoughts, or the body of deer, bears, and brown bears, always harboring fear.
If born among humans, one obtains two kinds of karmic retribution: first, many illnesses; second, cutting off life.'
Since killing and eating have such immeasurable and various karmic retributions, therefore, disciples!
Today, I bow my head and sincerely take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha of Dharma Wisdom in the East, Homage to the Buddha of Supreme Dharma in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Adornment in the West, Homage to the Buddha of Mastery in Wisdom in the North, Homage to the Buddha of Mastery in the Dharma of Rain Sounds in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of the King of Power in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of the Initial Intention in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of Renown in the Ten Directions in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of Reverence for the Dharma in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of Abundant Moon in the Zenith. I take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, this mind and consciousness have always harbored viciousness and lack compassion. Either killing out of greed, out of anger, out of delusion, or out of arrogance, or devising evil means, vowing to kill, or killing through spells, or breaking through lakes and ponds, burning mountains and fields, hunting and fishing, or setting fires with the wind, or flying hawks and releasing dogs, harming all the sentient beings of the six realms.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent.

Or using traps, snares, spears, halberds, bows, crossbows, and arrows to shoot flying birds and running beasts, or using nets, hooks, and traps to catch aquatic creatures such as fish, turtles, alligators, shrimp, clams, oysters, and other creatures that live in water, causing them to hide and flee with nowhere to go on land, in the water, or in the sky.

Or raising chickens, pigs, cattle, sheep, dogs, geese, ducks, and other animals to supply one's own kitchen, or selling them to be slaughtered, causing them to cry out in distress, their feathers plucked, their scales and fins damaged, their bodies and heads separated, their bones and flesh crushed, skinned, butchered, roasted, boiled, and grilled, cruelly and unjustly inflicting pain, just for a moment's pleasure, the taste obtained by the mouth is very little, no more than the tip of the tongue, three inches long.
Yet the retribution for such sins will bring misfortune for endless kalpas. I now confess these sins with utmost sincerity, taking refuge and repenting.

Furthermore, from beginningless time until today, we have either raised armies to attack each other, fought battles with opposing armies, faced each other in battle and killed each other, either killing ourselves or others, or hearing about killing and rejoicing, or engaging in butchery, debt, punishment, slaughtering the lives of others, and practicing intolerance, or indulging in anger, wielding weapons and brandishing knives, either beheading or stabbing, or pushing into pits or ravines, or drowning in water, or blocking holes and destroying nests, crushing with earth and stones, or using carts and horses to trample and crush all beings.
Like this, our offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today we confess and take refuge.

Furthermore, from beginningless time until now, we have either irrigated dry fields, aborted fetuses, destroyed eggs and nests, harmed and killed beings with poisonous drugs and sorcery, tilled the soil and planted fields, raised silkworms and boiled cocoons, raised cats and killed rats, causing great harm and killing.

Or beating mosquitoes, flies, bees, and scorpions, scratching lice, or burning to remove rubbish, digging ditches and canals, wantonly harming all beings, or eating fruits, using rice, water, or vegetables, killing insects indiscriminately, or burning firewood, exposing lamps and candles, burning various insects, or eating sauces and vinegar without looking at the stirring, or pouring boiling water to kill ants.
In this way, in the four deportments of walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, one always injures and kills the subtle beings in the air and on the ground.
Disciples!
Because of the ignorance of ordinary beings, one is unaware and does not know. Today, one confesses and takes refuge.
Moreover, disciples!

From beginningless time until today, one may have used whips, sticks, shackles, fetters, pressing, standing, beating, striking, kicking with hands and feet, binding, caging, or cutting off water and grain. In this way, one has used various evil means to torment beings.
Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge in the Buddhas of the ten directions, the honored Dharma, and the holy assembly, and repent.

May the disciples, by the merit generated from repenting of the offenses of killing and so forth, wish to be born in every life with an adamantine body and an infinite lifespan, forever free from resentment and enmity, without thoughts of killing or harming, and attain the stage of regarding all beings as one's only child.

If they see those in danger and distress, they will risk their lives to rescue and liberate them with skillful means, and then expound the subtle and correct Dharma for them. May all beings who see their form or shadow be granted peace and joy, and upon hearing their name or voice, may all their fears be dispelled.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Great Vehicle Lotus Treasure-Reaching Åšramaá¹‡a on Retribution, Chapter 1: Baota Previously Entered a Hell of Dismembered Bodies.
Why is it called the Hell of Dismembered Bodies?
The hell is thirty yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls and covered with an iron net above. In between, the raging fire blazes and burns, and iron pikes are spread all over the ground.
There were also flying daggers that stabbed the sinners, and a large iron rack that suspended the bodies of the sinners, dismembering them.
At that time, in the eastern gate, there were countless sinners who, from afar, saw this and wailed and cried out, throwing themselves to the ground and shouting,
What sins have we committed to come into this place?
The prison guards and yakshas held large axes in their hands and chopped at their heads, and then bound them with iron ropes. Fierce flames burned their bodies and flying daggers wildly stabbed them.

At that time, the sinners fell down step by step until they reached the rack. The prison guards and yakshas stretched out the sinners and used large iron saws to dismember them piece by piece. Blood flowed all over the ground and the pain was myriad-fold. There were the forms of sheep, cows, donkeys, horses, and various other animal forms, such as insects and birds. These animals came to drink their blood and then eat their flesh. The various animals all demanded from the sinners their past lives and the flesh they had eaten.
At that time, the sinful people had no words to answer, and the animals all gnawed at them.
The pain and suffering were unbearable, and the sinful people groaned with blood coming from their mouths and eyes, their sorrowful voices choking and reaching up to the heavens.

In this way, the suffering and poison lasted for a day and a night, with countless punishments received, dying a thousand times and being reborn a thousand times, dying ten thousand times and being reborn ten thousand times, passing through countless kalpas without any hope of release;
Later, if they were to escape, they would fall into the animal realm, being reborn hundreds of billions of times to be eaten by their enemies.
Bodhisattva Baodao asked:
What karma did these monks create that they are now experiencing this suffering?
The rÄká¹£asa replied:

These sinful people received the Buddha's precepts but did not seek the unsurpassed true wonderful Dharma. They only saw what was right before their eyes, believing in deviant and inverted views, being arrogant and indulgent with malicious intentions, lacking compassion and killing sentient beings, and cutting up the Buddha's kind.

Because of these causes and conditions, one receives such punishments. Later, even if one becomes a human, for hundreds or thousands of lifetimes, one's faculties will be incomplete, deaf, blind, mute, with incomplete hands and feet, with many sores on the body, constantly oozing pus and blood. Because of cutting off life, one will receive a short retribution.
When Baodao heard this, he wept sorrowfully and left.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
